Posts.Content: Dec 22, 2013 11:57PM Warrior_Woman wrote: I don't know if this will help or not.  It seems quite common to uncover more stuff as my surgeon described, "lurking in there".  I started off with a tiny IDC tumor and also planned for a lumpectomy with radiation.  The MRI uncovered LCIS in the same breast which normally is present in the other as well.  I then consulted with SIX doctors because my OCD is worse than yours (smile).  In my case I could go either way but two things swayed my decision to have a BMX.  First, there is little research about the effect of radiation on LCIS and that wasn't needed with a BMX in my case.  Second, as a person who worries too much over everything, I did not want to live my life with constant screenings, call backs, biopsies, yada yada.  I figured my mental health was worth something too.  All 6 docs agreed my decision was rational and good for ME...not for everyone but for me.  My post pathology report revealed DCIS too.  I am very glad I opted for a BMX.  I am healing well and sometime later this year I will have the boobies of a 20 year old.  The difference here is that my BMX was my choice and not one made for me.  I am sorry and I do hope you find peace with this along the way.

Posts.Content: Dec 23, 2013 08:51AM - edited Dec 23, 2013 08:52AM by Warrior_Woman Bobogirl is back!  You've been missed.  I'm concerned we haven't heard from Carebear since her hospital discharge after her infection.  Hzzr - Did you see the forum for singles on here?  I've been single most of my life and managing is more difficult.  My cousin went through BC when she was single and said she never felt more alone in her life.  All the more reason to ask for help from the services available and reach out to those who have the capacity to offer support and assistance.  Some people want to help and letting them know what they can do may make them feel they're doing good.   Paloverde & Sam2U - I know you're frightened.  Unfortunately I've learned not to trust the predictions of doctors.  The accuracy feels about as clear as the psychic hotline.  My ki67 is 40% and I will leave Christmas Eve dinner to meet with my Onc to go over my Oncotype Dx.  It just feels like surgery should be enough suffering for one disease and then when chemo is lumped on top it seems like too much.  The good part of higher ki67 is that it eats up the chemo.  If I'm correct it means a favorable response to chemo but please don't quote me.   A few days after my diagnosis when my head was still spinning and I had no idea what would happen or what to expect, I wandered into a boutique and purchased a bunch of scarves.  Speaking with the sales woman I mentioned I will need them for chemo as that was my assumption.  She looked at me and said, "Honey you will be fine.  I went through all that breast cancer mess 18 years ago.  When you come out on the other side you will be different.  You will be changed.  You will be a better person and you will like yourself more."  I think of her almost everyday.   I'm glad to be here with all of you.  Some days I feel I can offer strength and other days I thank you for being here for me.   Clawing and Soaring.

Posts.Content: Jan 5, 2014 03:00AM Warrior_Woman wrote: NjMom - I just found out I will be a chemo chick.  For ER+/PR+/HER2 - women with little or no node invasion, the Oncotype Dx test is often performed to determine need and benefit for chemo.  Depending upon the results, many women with low score move on to hormone treatment and skip chemo.  It is considered for them to be of little or no benefit.  Women with high score need chemo and it should benefit them greatly.  Women with intermediate scores must weight the risks and benefits.  In my case I had an intermediate score and determined chemo is in my better interest.  Sucks but I won't look back and regret not having done all I can to prevent a recurrence.  Also, I love not wearing a bra.  I bought 2 coobie bras with stuffing pads at the Faith and Hope shop but only wore them over the holidays.

Posts.Content: Dec 15, 2013 10:44AM Warrior_Woman wrote: CareBear! Our surgeries were the same day. Please kick that stupid infection out of your system. Thank you for giving us the update. Posts.Content: Dec 27, 2013 06:40AM Warrior_Woman wrote: paloverde - Do you have an occupational therapist?  I had one come to my home for the first two weeks after surgery and she greatly improved my range of motion.  I am almost back to normal in my ability to stretch with some mild limitations when I pull my right elbow over my head.  I'm pleased with my progress and the occupational therapist did a great job of guiding me through the recovery process.  I simply did not know what I should and should not be attempting to do.   Ladies - I don't have any zingers although I was told to expect them.  I also don't have muscle spasms although I was given Valium that I stopped taking.  I see my PS Monday.  I assume the lack of these sensations is normal too but I'm going to check.  Currently the only things bothering me is the sensation of wearing an underwire bra when I don't have one on and in the evening feeling like the "bra" (expanders) has tightened and the looong stupid delay for my Oncotype score.

Posts.Content: Jan 5, 2014 05:52PM Warrior_Woman wrote: Blissful - My BMX was 12/4 and I've been following the progress of the women on this thread.  There is a wide range of recovery experiences.  Several of our friends are still hospitalized with infections and other complications.  Some have range of motion difficulties and other discomforts.  I am doing very well and have returned to normal activity including running and other exercise.  I stretch a lot and notice that my right elbow stretched over my head causes a pulling sensation that I reported to my doctor.  With this said, it is my uninformed opinion that you should be talking with your surgeon asap.  I am concerned that you're swollen and have burning pain.  I ran to my doctor for every little concern.  One time I rushed in with a symptom that had me so frightened and she told me to stop staring at my hair follicles.  May I ask why you're not a reconstruction candidate?  Over the holidays I wore a Coobie bra from the faith and hope shop.  It has insertable pads and is very soft.  The shops that help women with BC are fantastic.  They offer so much.  I haven't been to one of the LOOK GOOD FEEL BETTER meetings yet but I plan to go.  There is a thread here for women who have chosen not to have reconstruction and I bet they've come up with some creative, artistic and powerful ideas.

Posts.Content: Jan 24, 2014 06:57AM Warrior_Woman wrote: NJMom - Chemo sucks.  It's toxic waste pumped into your body in an effort to kill everything without killing you.  I second the suggestion to drink water - In fact, drink a gallon a day for the first week.  I mix in 1/4 cup of pure organic cranberry juice once a day.  The night after chemo, each time you get up to pee, drink another glass of water.  The other suggestion is to keep moving.  Get enough exercise even when you don't feel like it. As I see it, the decision for chemo is an easy one for both of us.  A score of 17 would have made me insane.   SwimMom - Please check with your surgeon. Each of us is different.  I had a snb of one node on my right and now use my left arm for everything even after my BMX.  I asked my surgeon about the sleeve and she said "NO!"  While my risk of LE is about 5%, I do need to take precautions but the sleeve is not a good idea for me.

Posts.Content: Feb 21, 2015 04:04AM - edited Feb 21, 2015 04:05AM by Warrior_Woman Leslie & Lynda - The point of my post is that according to Dr. Susan Love there is no relationship between antiperspirants & BC. In other words, when Frank told me to use an aluminum free deodorant he was restating an internet myth. If you like organic deodorants that's great. But if you're like me and find that they are less effective than what you used formerly, there is no BC related reason to continue to use a product you're not happy with. I'm switching back to my Powder Fresh Secret. I'm all for making lifestyle changes to reduce recurrence risk but I'm not standing on my head because someone heard that being erect causes cancer.  "Myth: Deodorant and antiperspirants cause breast cancer. Fact: Skipping these toiletries won't keep your breasts cancer free. One email rumor claimed that antiperspirant prevents you from sweating out toxins, which can then accumulate in the lymph nodes and cause breast cancer. But in 2002, researchers at the Fred Hutchinson Cancer Research Center in Seattle conducted a study to address this rumor—and found no link between deodorant or antiperspirant and breast cancer. A second rumor speculated that certain chemicals in antiperspirants, such as aluminum and parabens, may cause breast cancer because there is a lower prevalence of the disease in developing countries where women don't use these products. However, toxins are not usually released through sweat, and in Europe, where antiperspirants are not widely used, the rate of breast cancer is higher than it is in the United States. Finally, although a 2004 study found parabens in the tissue of breast cancer tumors, so far no studies have shown that these or any other chemicals in deodorants and antiperspirants cause breast cancer."

Posts.Content: Jan 30, 2015 09:43PM Warrior_Woman wrote: Goldenpaws - When I started here a year ago I read every single post on the main CC thread. It took a few days. I was looking for patterns, suggestions, warnings and anything that would help me predict what would happen. Like you, I did the TC. I recorded everyone's data and paid particular attention to the TC women. I also read every published journal I could find. Here's what I concluded: Research shows women doing the TC do well with the caps. Hair loss ranges from very little and the most reported loss is 50%. I lost about 50% so I did not do as well as many. I'm mostly vegetarian and that could have made the difference...I don't know. No TC women in the studies lost more than 50%. And as you can see, with 50% hair loss, it does start filling in quickly. If not for the caps I'd be walking around today with a short curly cork screw hairdo. Some women can pull it off well. I'm not one of them. Also, I tracked patterns of hair loss. Some shed after each chemo. Some shed little during chemo only to lose a lot afterwards. And some, like me, shed a lot early on, were steady the rest of the way through and tapered off quickly PFC. I lost most of my hair day 17-30. I've posted this before but this is what I lost in just one day....  I was a weirdo who saved my hair in baggies. In fact, I was such a weirdo that after saving all my hair I did not know what to do with it and decided to make a hairy voodoo doll. And here she is....  The bottom line is that I survived this. My hair is looking good and getting better and you will survive this too. I have concluded that there are many different patterns of shedding and we're all predestined to lose our older hair. Some will lose more and some less. Some sooner and some later. It is horribly stressful to have hair sliding off your head. But then it stops. And we start to breathe again.

Posts.Content: Jun 19, 2015 02:18AM Warrior_Woman wrote: Hi Tiffany, I remember the anguish of trying to make this decision. My MO asked me how I thought I'd feel after a lumpectomy and after a BMX. I'm a very anxious person to begin with and wanted to lower my risk of a local recurrence. I think you know that a BMX does not lower your risk of a systemic recurrence and we all have concern about that. Still, I did not want more mammograms and call backs so I chose the BMX. This was the right decision for me but not everyone. Part of my decision was also due to multiple diagnosis as indicated on my signature line. I feel good about my decision. Most women have tissue expanders and implants but there are many reconstruction options. After my first attempt failed I had flaps with my back muscles. That is not the first choice for most women but should you find that is your decision I am glad to talk with you.

Posts.Content: Mar 4, 2014 07:47AM Warrior_Woman wrote: Lisaj - I agonized a lot over my decision for a mastectomy over lumpectomy and rads.  There is a lot to consider including what you mentioned about reconstruction options if there is a recurrence.  Either option leaves the same risk for a systemic recurrence and mastectomy only reduces the risk of a local recurrence.  In my case, with LCIS dx on top of everything else they found, the mastectomy was a good choice.  There is no research of the effects of radiation on LCIS.  My MO helped me decide when he asked how I would feel after with either decision I may make.  I expected to be sad for a while with a mastectomy but worry forever with constant screenings and call backs with a lumpectomy.  Turns out I'm not sad at all.  For me this is the right decision but only based upon my individual circumstances.   Mmm - Have you posted on the Cold Cap thread?  Everyone there is using them or has used the caps.  I'm on day 49 and still have my hair.  No one can tell I am doing chemo.  We have different regimes and I cannot recall the outcomes for yours.  I recently posted my observations of the patterns of shedding based upon having read through the thousands of posts on the thread.  You can go back a few days to read it.  I do not have a port and it is rough on my veins.  One of my veins is black.  I have some swelling.  I hope to get through one last infusion.  Ugh.

Posts.Content: Feb 13, 2016 09:13PM Warrior_Woman wrote: I am with shannondunlap and owlwatcher. Addiction is a medical condition and so is breast cancer. No one wants breast cancer. No one wants to be substance dependent. The approach to treatment for many years has been one of pain management and in the course of treatment many people became dependent on their prescription medications. The problem with the opiates is that the withdrawal increases the subjective experience of pain. EVERYONE who takes them develops a certain tolerance. Tolerance occurs with every substance. It's easy to see how a vicious cycle can begin. The pendulum has not swung in the opposite direction as the treatment protocols have not changed. Many doctors are more cautious given the alarming incidence of death by overdose. My docs will still hand them to me like candy and this is frightening. I've had 9 surgeries for BC and was loaded down with pain killers each time. They assume because I am high functioning that I won't develop a dependence. Anyone can become an addict. I've addressed this with them directly and the response is that they doubt I will. If I do I should alert them and me medically managed for the withdrawal. I've known more people who've died from addiction in recent years than BC. None of them sucked! Glad you got what you wanted, Marg. Proceed with caution.

Posts.Content: Jan 1, 2014 10:29AM Warrior_Woman wrote: Paloverde - Here's where I am now based upon a long discussion with my Onc and my position is subject to change.  If I am intermediate I will do the chemo because like many here, I too want to do all I can and not have regrets.  If I am below 12 (unlikely) I won't do chemo.  If I am between 12 - 18 I will look at the chart on page 2 of the report to determine the extent to which to chemo will lower my risk.  3% risk reduction or greater and I am doing chemo.  1% probably not.  2%...maybe not.  Part of the reason for my decision is my high ki67 at 40% which is questioned because it doesn't fit with my overall profile.  I don't have great confidence in the lab that reported it as they got another pathology report wrong.  One small study said that it's the high ki67s that are the ones in the low RS who have recurrence.  Other studies show that for women like myself with low mitotic scores (1) and high ki67s the mitotic scores clearly trump the ki67.  In your situation there are too many risk factors that lean toward chemo.  I really thought I would be positive for a BRCA mutation but I am not so they're doing the other BC genetic tests.    I will be getting two different professional opinions before making a final chemo decision.  We may be going through this together.

Posts.Content: Jan 10, 2014 12:55AM Warrior_Woman wrote: The most important chart to look at is on the 2nd page of the report.  The first page has your score and you;ll know a lot when it pops off the page.  It's in big font and there is no missing it.  The 2nd page shows the difference in your recurrence risk with and without chemo.  Look at the point where  the lines separate.  This is where decisions start needed to be made.  With a score of 24 my recurrence risk is 15%.  Way too high for me!  With chemo it gets knocked down to about 8%.  Add Tamoxifen and we're now closer to 5%.  5% isn't 0 but it is certainly better than 15% and will make the difference between sleeping and not sleeping.

Posts.Content: Dec 20, 2013 09:26PM - edited Dec 20, 2013 10:14PM by Warrior_Woman MsPharoah - THANK YOU!  I have scoured the internet looking for something like this and I greatly appreciate your sharing it.  Please confirm that I did this correctly, if you would please.  I entered my data in the green sections of the first column as I am HER2 negative and used a 0 for the Her2 number (my Her2neu score is +1).  I entered ER/PR based upon the 300 scale.  I calculated my score twice for each of the three regression analysis sections.  The first time I used the numbers provided by my first pathology report from my original biopsy and the second time I used the slightly different numbers from my post mastectomy pathology report.  All three recurrence scores for my first pathology report were around 19 and my second scores were 15.55, 13.55 and 17.23.  Does this description sound to you like I did this correctly?  I am really on the border.  My ki67 is 40% and I know that will kick it up a bit.  I am such a numbers person and I know we're more than numbers.  Nonetheless, I really appreciate this resource.   Coreleliz - The cost of the test leads some docs to order the test when the outcome isn't obvious.  My surgeon waited until my pathology report came back. If it were up to me they would have sent for it immediately.

Posts.Content: Sep 11, 2015 09:26PM - edited Sep 11, 2015 09:26PM by Warrior_Woman Hello Ailish - Has the gene in your family been identified? Unfortunately, there a more than two genes that are linked to breast cancer. The two most are familiar with are BRCA1 & BRCA2. Those are the ones they normally test for first. However, there are other gene mutations they will test for with individuals who come up negative on the BRCA1 & 2 tests. BCO just posted an article that covers the new guidelines for patient management around genetic testing. This link will take you there: Genetics You may want to speak with a genetic counselor. The counselor can advise you of a suitable path for your care. I have 2 mutations of the NF1 gene and it is linked both to breast cancer as well as some other cancers and other health conditions. The problem in my situation is that there isn't a darn thing I can do to prevent the other forms of cancer and all are fatal when diagnosed. And so, I now have information that only leads me to worry. I asked my genetic counselor not to tell me my test results unless I could use the information proactively. She ignored my request and told me anyway. You will read in the guidelines the recommendations for considering situations like this to avoid unnecessary anxiety for patients. Ultimately, a well trained genetic counselor will be able to talk with you and help you to make the decisions that are right for you. All the best for you and your family.

Posts.Content: Jan 5, 2014 09:29PM Warrior_Woman wrote: I was also diagnosed 9/13.  What a crappy 4 months it has been.  I was planning for a lumpectomy and radiation until LCIS was discovered.  While not a cancer it is a high risk marker and would mean a high chance for recurrence, constant screenings and chronic anxiety.  I decided to go for the BMX and for me it was a good decision.  My Oncologist asked me how I expected to feel with both choices.  With a lumpectomy I would live a life of high anxiety.  With a mastectomy I expected to still worry about recurrence but not as much and I expected to grieve the loss of my breasts.  My mental health has value too and I chose the BMX.  The surgery was far easier than I expected.  One month out and I'm back at the gym and running 5 miles a day.  I have TEs and will have implants at some point.  I'll get new nipples and tattoos.  I avoided the SEs of radiation and I don't feel sad about losing my breasts.  I'm hoping for decent replacements.  Now I have to go for chemo and that will suck but I'll survive and you will too.  There are many reconstruction options.  I chose the TEs because I did not want to be cut elsewhere.  Fat from my stomach would mean taking muscle and there is no chance I would allow that. I am looking forward to going braless.  I am happy with my decision.  It was best for me.  Keep talking it out and you'll find your way.
